Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating the Drivers of Invasive Raccoon Spread in Japan and its Effects on the Native Raccoon Dog
Award.AbstractNarration:
Invasive species are the second largest cause of global species extinction after habitat destruction, and they have an especially strong impact on islands. The North American raccoon, introduced to Japan in the 1970?s, has since infiltrated forested and urban areas country-wide and poses a significant wildlife management problem. It is thought to affect many native species, including the charismatic raccoon dog, but its impacts are not well understood. The researcher will work with Professor Fumito Koike of Yokohama National University, an expert on invasive species and spatial modeling, to investigate the factors causing the raccoon?s spread. The research team will use various environmental variables to model raccoon movement. They will also use camera 'traps' placed in areas predicted by the model to determine impact on the raccoon dog. This research will contribute modeling techniques and field methods useful for invasive species management both in Japan and elsewhere.

Invasive species are the second largest cause of global species extinction after habitat destruction, and they have an especially strong impact on islands, where endemism is high and movement is restricted. The North American raccoon, introduced to Japan in the 1970?s, has since infiltrated forested and urban areas country-wide and poses a significant wildlife management problem. It is thought to affect many native species, including the charismatic raccoon dog, but its impacts are not well understood. The researcher will work with Professor Fumito Koike of Yokohama National University, an expert on invasive species and spatial modeling, to investigate the drivers of invasive spread by simulating raccoon movement over various resistance surfaces of differing complexity (e.g. land use, ecological niche models). They will use camera traps placed in areas predicted by the model to measure both species' abundances and quantify impact on the raccoon dog. This research will contribute modeling techniques and field methods useful for invasive species management both in Japan and elsewhere.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Jamie M. Kass completed his EAPSI fellowship in the summer of 2016 in Japan. During the funding period, he worked in the lab of Dr. Fumito Koike, an expert on invasive species and spatial modeling, at Yokohama National University. In Japan, the invasive North American raccoon has spread across most of the country since the 1960's, and is responsible for damage to crops and buildings of great cultural value, disease transmission, and predation on endangered species. Kass was interested in developing models that could determine the relationships between environment variables and raccoon presence and spread, and what effects raccoons may be having on populations of native carnivores. This research contributed directly to Kass’s dissertation on the effects that biotic interactions (for example, competition or predation) have on species ranges. Additionally, the results of this research are intended to inform invasive species managers and help prioritize areas for control.

Kass was able to accomplish several research goals while in Japan. He traveled to several parts of the country to interview environmental managers about how they manage invasive raccoons and what kinds of data they take. Through these interactions, he was able to acquire raccoon trapping data for both Osaka and Kanagawa prefectures (states). He also visited temples and shrines in Kyoto where raccoons had damaged buildings of high cultural value, and spoke to priests and monks about their unique approaches to the problem. In addition, Kass was able to conduct camera trapping surveys at Yokohama National University and a state park in Kanagawa. Most of his time was spent in the lab working on modeling and mapping analyses, and he benefitted greatly from interactions with Dr. Koike and his graduate students.

The analyses focused on the data from Kanagawa, which was a 6-year raccoon trapping effort by local stakeholders that resulted in some bycatch of other carnivores. Based on this data and environmental variables for Japan (percent forest cover, stream density, etc.), Kass developed a model that predicts raccoon presence based on the environment at a site. The model indicates that raccoon presence is more likely with increasing forest, agriculture, and stream density, but less likely with increasing road density. The model also indicates that although raccoons are likely to colonize areas with low forest cover, they are not likely to survive in these areas. Thus, management control might be more effective by targeting highly forested areas where self-supporting populations are most likely to exist. Results also suggest that raccoons are more likely to be found where other carnivores are present, both native and invasive. Therefore, indiscriminant trapping where raccoons are in high abundance could also impact native carnivores.

Kass continues to work with his doctoral advisory committee, Dr. Koike, and other Japanese collaborators on this research. He has presented his work thus far as a poster at the 8th Biennial Conference of the International Biogeography Society.
